content:
Lupus nephritis: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis, prevention

Lupus nephritis is one of the common complications in people with systemic lupus erythematosus. Kidney disease can become severe over time, possibly leading to end-stage chronic kidney failure. Once end-stage kidney failure occurs, the patient will need hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis or a kidney transplant to maintain life.

What is lupus nephritis?
Lupus nephritis is kidney damage in lupus (lupus glomerulonephritis) due to the mechanism of immune complexes circulating in the circulation to deposit in the glomerulus. It is found that there is a relationship between the concentration of anti-DNA antibodies in the serum of patients with glomerular disease, as well as the level of immune complex deposition in the glomeruli of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus. (first)
Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease. In people with autoimmune diseases, instead of attacking substances that harm the body, the immune system attacks healthy tissues and organs, including the kidneys.
​
This condition can lead to kidney inflammation, blood in the urine, protein in the urine, high blood pressure, impaired kidney function, and even kidney failure. About 60% of people with systemic lupus erythematosus develop kidney complications. Lupus nephritis develops early and progresses very quickly.

Symptoms of lupus nephritis
Symptoms of lupus nephritis are similar to other kidney diseases, specifically: (2)
Dark urine; Foaming or blood in urine; Increased need to urinate, especially at night; Weight gain.; High Blood Pressure.
Symptoms of the disease do not appear often and tend to be intermittent. Therefore, kidney damage is often detected through urine test results.
However, people with systemic lupus erythematosus should note: Not all problems in the urinary system are signs of lupus nephritis. Some cases may be a sign of a urinary tract infection.

Causes of lupus nephritis
The main cause of lupus nephritis is systemic lupus erythematosus. Among the causes of disease, genetics plays the most important role. Many genes have yet to be identified that are associated with this condition. Normally, the immune system is the barrier that protects the body from infection. However, when problems arise, the immune system cannot distinguish between harmful and healthy substances. (3)
Autoimmunity contributes significantly to the pathophysiology of lupus glomerulonephritis. Autoantibodies directed against nuclear factors. Characteristics of lupus nephritis include:
Antigens specifically target nucleosomes.; Autoantibodies with high affinity form intravascular immune complexes (autoantibodies are small in size, only about 200bp); Autoantibodies of certain isotypes trigger complement activation.

Classification of kidney histopathological lesions
WHO has classified histopathological lesions in systemic lupus erythematosus into 6 classes, specifically:
Class I: Normal glomeruli: No clinical manifestations appear. Urine and kidney function test results are normal.; Class II: Mesangial lupus glomerulonephritis. At that time, kidney damage was more obvious with symptoms including hematuria, possibly accompanied by low proteinuria. Some rarer cases include nephrotic syndrome; Class III: Local and segmental proliferative lupus glomerulonephritis. About 15-20% of patients have impaired kidney function and about 1⁄3 have nephrotic syndrome; Class IV: Diffuse proliferative lupus glomerulonephritis. More than 50% of important blood vessels in the kidney are damaged. Patients with nephrotic syndrome often have impaired kidney function.; Class V : Membranous lupus glomerulonephritis. Nephrotic syndrome is the most common clinical sign. Patients may then be prescribed dialysis or kidney transplant.; Class VI: Glomerulosclerosis ( advanced glomerulonephritis) is a common condition in cases of nephritis several years ago. Clinical manifestations include kidney failure, high blood pressure and nephrotic syndrome. More than 90% of important blood vessels in the kidneys lose their ability to function. functional ability.

Risk factors
Out of every 10,000 people in the world, 3 people have lupus nephritis. The disease is more common in women than men, between the ages of 20 and 40. Factors that can increase the risk of disease include:
Genetics.; Sex.; Environmental factors: Tobacco, shingles virus, stress...

When to see a doctor?
Early diagnosis and treatment will help prevent lupus nephritis from getting worse and avoid emergency situations. Therefore, patients should quickly go to reputable medical facilities for examination, diagnosis and early intervention measures to prevent dangerous complications.

How is lupus nephritis diagnosed?
The diagnosis process will begin with a medical history, physical examination and assessment of symptoms. After that, the patient may be prescribed necessary tests or diagnostic imaging, specifically:
1. Blood and urine tests
Blood tests: Assess waste levels such as creatinine, urea.; 24-hour urine collection: Measures the kidney's ability to filter waste and determines protein concentration in the urine.; Urine test: Check kidney function, measure protein concentration, white blood cells and red blood cells.; Iothalamate clearance test: This test is performed by injecting radioactive Iothalamate into the patient's blood. The doctor will then test how quickly the substance is filtered from the blood and excreted into the urine.
2. Kidney biopsy
A biopsy is the most accurate method for diagnosing lupus kidney disease. This method uses a long needle inserted through the back (hip) and into the kidney under ultrasound guidance, then takes a sample of kidney tissue to analyze signs of damage. The biopsy results will help doctors determine the stage of the disease, thereby providing appropriate treatment.
3. Ultrasound
This diagnostic method will use sound waves to create detailed images of the patient's kidneys. From there, doctors can detect abnormalities in the kidneys, but they are of little value in the early stages and are only of reference value for lupus kidney disease.

How to treat lupus nephritis
Current world medicine still cannot completely treat lupus nephritis. Treatments only help reduce symptoms, slow disease progression, and reduce the risk of dialysis and kidney transplant. Depending on each person's medical condition, the doctor may prescribe medications such as:
Corticosteroids: Medicines that reduce inflammation. Doctors often prescribe use until the inflammation improves. However, the drug has some serious side effects. Therefore, patients need to use medication exactly as directed by the doctor.; Immunosuppressive drugs: Azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, voclosporin, mycophenolate... can inhibit the activity of the immune system, causing damage to the kidneys.; Medications to control blood pressure: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) help prevent protein from leaking from the kidneys into the urine.; Medicines to prevent blood clot formation (if needed).; Even with treatment, loss of kidney function may continue to develop. If drug treatment is no longer effective, the doctor may prescribe dialysis. This method helps remove fluid and waste from the body, maintain balance of minerals in the blood, and control blood pressure.
If medical treatment is not effective, the doctor may prescribe dialysis
A kidney transplant is often the final treatment for people with lupus nephritis.

Preventing and controlling lupus kidney disease
Given the dangerous complications above, preventing and controlling lupus nephritis is extremely important. We need to have a healthy lifestyle and activities such as:
Drink enough water every day, about 1.5 - 2l.; Healthy diet: Make sure to add enough nutrients to your menu every day. Limit intake of sodium-rich foods for people with high blood pressure; Limit alcohol, beer and smoking; Limit intake of foods high in cholesterol; Regularly exercise with appropriate intensity; Do not take medication without consulting your doctor.
